In its core, the Yoast Duplicate Post plugin allows you to simply make a copy of a post or a page. That\u2019s it! But this opens up a whole range of possibilities \u2014 from building a complete editorial flow to quickly build landing pages to boost your SEO.\n\n\n\nSimply Clone a post or make a New Draft to start working on it right away\n\n\n\nAwesome, right? Best of all, it\u2019s free! Find out why over 3 million users trust the Yoast Duplicate Post plugin to save them precious time and prevents frustrations.\n\n\n\nDownload it now on WordPress.org \u00bb\n\n\n\nWhat does Yoast Duplicate Post do?\n\n\n\nThe Yoast Duplicate Post plugin lets you duplicate any post or page in WordPress \u2014 with one click. Of course, you could copy a page by hand if you like, but that doesn\u2019t duplicate things like the featured image, meta data or the SEO optimizations you\u2019ve made in Yoast SEO. The Yoast Duplicate Post plugin allows you to copy everything over, with one click. It is always easier and faster to start from a copy!\n\n\n\nWhat do people use the Yoast Duplicate Post plugin for?\n\n\n\nA lot! Here at Yoast, it has become an integral part of our editorial workflow. We do a lot of content updates and we don\u2019t like to work in the published version of the post. For big updates, we always make a copy. In that copy, we do our work \u2014 updating the content, replacing images and improving the SEO of articles. Once done, we copy everything back to the original post and delete the draft. Easy peasy!\n\n\n\nThis is just one example. People like to duplicate posts and pages for loads of things:\n\n\n\n\nAs a way to quickly convert existing sales pages for new products\n\n\n\nTo make backups of all-important posts and pages\n\n\n\nSpeed up the process of making posts that look very much alike\n\n\n\nExpand your event listings in a jiffy by copying an existing template\n\n\n\nBuilt a site? Have your customer easily populate a site by filling in the drafts\n\n\n\nEt cetera\n\n\n\nEt cetera\n\n\n\n\nThe main takeaway? This plugin helps you speed up your processes and improve your workflow. All that with a simple Clone button.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFeatures of the Yoast Duplicate Post plugin\n\n\n\nThe Duplicate Post plugin is built to blend into the background, allowing you to work without noticing it. You can customize the plug so that it fulfils its duty in a way that makes sense to you.\n\n\n\nTwo modes: Clone or New Draft\n\n\n\nThe Yoast Duplicate Post plugin adds two simple links to your post overview: Clone and New Draft. Simply click the Clone button to make a copy of that specific post or page. Click the New Draft link to copy that post or page and open it in the editor right away. You can also do this straight from the admin bar in the post editor or from the post settings itself \u2014 look for the Copy to a new draft link.\n\n\n\nCopy to a new draft straight from the WordPress admin bar\n\n\n\nSet the plugin to your likingYou can fine-tune the plugin to your liking. In the settings, you determine exactly what the plugin does and doesn\u2019t duplicate for you. In the settings, you can also change where the copy page buttons appear.\n\n\n\nChange which post or page elements you want to copy to a new draft\n\n\n\nDetermine which roles get to do what\n\n\n\nAs a site manager, you can also determine who of your editors get access to the page duplication features. This also includes the SEO roles that Yoast SEO introduced. \n\n\n\nManage the appearance of connections\n\n\n\nYou can also determine how the connections between the copy and the original appearance. It might be a new column in the post overview or simply a not after the title. You can also have the original article appear in the post editor, including the block editor sidebar.\n\n\n\nYou can clear up the connection between the draft and the original in various ways\n\n\n\nNew: Rewrite &amp; Republish feature\n\n\n\nRewriting a post has always been quite a struggle in WordPress. But not anymore! Keep your content manageable with the brand-new Rewrite &amp; Republish feature. It allows you to seamlessly edit your content within WordPress, without taking it offline. Updating your content has never been easier!\n\n\n\nYou can access the Rewrite &amp; Republish feature via the WordPress toolbar or from the post overview\n\n\n\nHow does it work? When you click the Rewrite &amp; Republish button, a new duplicated version of your original post is created. You edit the duplicated version and after you\u2019re done, your duplicated post will be merged into the original post! Automatically deleting the duplicated version and updating the original post, maintaining the original URL. And, you can schedule these updates as well! This feature also works seamlessly in Elementor.\n\n\n\nCurious to see how this brand-new feature works? Check out this video!\n\n\n\n\nhttps://youtu.be/te8rzwa1GYc\n\n\n\n\nThere\u2019s more to come!\n\n\n\nThe Duplicate Post WordPress plugin is a recent addition to the Yoast stable. And if you don't know what good copy is for SEO, then we have courses about that in our academy. We can talk about a whole lot of technical things but, if we\u2019re honest, the reality is these days they don't matter that much if your site is reasonably fast. Or is a link on the main page to a different page with a lot of text better for SEO?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "By\u00a0the main page, do you mean the homepage? In which case, probably not as a home page has quite a specific role. It's designed to help people see immediately where I am, what thing is this? What business is it? What site is it? What are my options? What are the top three or four things I can do and help them get through to that page? And if you've got a decent brand and you set your sights on that, your homepage really should be ranking for those key brand terms. Don't cram your homepage full of thousands of words for the sake of it, put them in the right place, put them where they make sense. \u00a0", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://yoast.com/webinar/seo-news-mar-2022/#faq-question-1648651554738", "position": 4, "url": "https://yoast.com/webinar/seo-news-mar-2022/#faq-question-1648651554738", "name": "Does Google treat Pages differently than Posts?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "There are some differences internally in WordPress, like does it have an author and can it be paginated, and does it have\u00a0other bits? But is it a URL with words on it, then Google doesn't treat it differently? The whole concept of pages and posts is not something that Google sees. We\u00a0wish it did, but it doesn't. So, it's just text on the page regardless of the type in WordPress. I have around 600 posts and pages on my website and I was wondering if redirecting (301) has any impact on my SEO? Is it possible that I will drop into Google? And will it slow my page speed down?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "This topic keeps popping up. Honestly, yes you will see a slight drop in Google for a bit. It depends on how often Google crawls your site and how fast your site is and a couple of other factors on how fast that'll go. It could be anywhere between a couple of days and a couple of weeks. This is why we usually say don't change redirects. Or don't change slugs if it's not really a good improvement, that's what you should think about here.
